nodes.text: An IoT based system using Node MCU and Wi-Fi can implement integrated smart home automation and smart security that overcomes short-range and reliability drawbacks of existing wireless methods
Existing wireless home automation approaches (Bluetooth, ZigBee, GSM, voice recognition) have limitations: limited range, dependence on Bluetooth range or SNR, low reliability of GSM SMS delivery
Proposed architecture uses Node MCU as primary controller, Arduino UNO for camera, sensors including IR, MQ135, DHT11, OV7670 camera, relay board, connected via Wi-Fi to a smartphone or internet

System operation integrates three functions: smart security (IR-triggered image capture and email alert), remote home automation (control lights and fans from smartphone over internet or 3G/4G), and environment monitoring (temperature, humidity, air quality readings sent to phone)
The implementation overcomes short-range limits of Bluetooth and ZigBee by using Wi-Fi and mobile data, and addresses GSM unreliability by using internet email delivery of alerts and images
Motivation: overcome those existing drawbacks by implementing an IoT based smart security and home automation prototype
Hardware selection: Node MCU chosen for Wi-Fi connectivity and multiple sensor connections; Arduino UNO used to interface the OV7670 camera due to analog pin limitations on Node MCU
Sensors and actuators: IR sensor for motion detection, OV7670 camera for capture, MQ135 for air quality, DHT11 for temperature and humidity, 4-channel 5V relay board to switch appliances

Software and interface: system updates sensor values to a web server and displays real-time readings and control on a smartphone app (Blink), and sends captured images via email to predefined owner address
Security workflow result: when IR detects motion, camera is activated, image is captured and stored on PC, and the image is sent to the owner by email as an intruder alert
Home automation workflow result: owner can remotely switch lights and fans via smartphone over internet or mobile data, enabling long distance control and assistance for handicapped and elderly users
Environment monitoring result: DHT11 and MQ135 provide per-second temperature, humidity and air quality readings to the smartphone; high values can trigger fans to ventilate
Claim supported by prototype: the implemented low cost prototype demonstrates combined security, automation and monitoring features with remote access and email alerting
Advantages observed: low cost, minimal requirements, remote device control, helpful for handicapped and aged people, time saving
Limitation and future scope: system requires internet connectivity to operate; authors note Wi-Fi alternatives via 3G/4G and suggest possible implementation using Raspberry Pi
